column2: '15Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: the Social Security -- you're an expert and I could
column5: I'm sure
column6: learn from you the details of the Pension Guarantee Fund and the Social Security Fund. The Social Security system was fixed about 5 years
column7: and I think it's projected out to be sound beyond that. So at least we have time to work with it. But on all of these things
column8: a sound economy is the only way to get it going. Growth in the economy is gonna add to the overall prosperity and wealth. I can't give you a specific answer on Pension Guarantee Fund. All I know is that we have firm government credit to guarantee the pensions. And that is very important. But it's -- the full faith and credit of the US
column9: in spite of our difficulties
column10: is still pretty good. It's still the most respected credit.  So I would simply say
column11: as these dates get close
column12: you're going to have to reorganize and refix as we did with the Social Security Fund. And I think that's the only answer. But the more immediate answer is to do what this lady was suggesting we do
column13: and that is to get this deficit down and get on without adding to the woes
column14: and then restructure.  One thing I've called for that has been stymied
column15: and I'll keep on working for it
column16: is a whole financial reform legislation. It is absolutely essential in terms of bringing our banking system and credit system into the new age instead of having it living back in the dark ages. And it's a big fight. And I don't want to give my friend Ross another shot at me here but I am fighting with the Congress to get this through. And you can't just go up and say I'm going to fix it. You've got some pretty strong-willed guys up there that argue with you.  But that's what the election's about. I agree with the governor. That's what the election's about. And sound fiscal policy is the best answer
column18: to all the three problems you mentioned.

column1: On the broad issue here
column2: when you're trying to solve a problem
column3: you get the best plans. You have a raging debate about those plans. Then out of that debate
column4: with leadership
column5: comes consensus. Then
column6: if the plans are huge and complex like health care
column7: I would urge you to implement pilot programs. Like the old carpenter says measure twice
column8: cut once. Let's make sure this thing's as good as we all think it is at the end of the meeting. Then finally
column9: our government passes laws and freezes the plan in concrete. Anybody that's ever built a successful business will tell you you optimize
column10: optimize
column11: optimize after you've put something into effect. The reason Medicare and Medicaid are a mess is we froze them.  Everybody knows how to fix them. There are people all over the federal government
column12: if they could just touch it with a screwdriver
column13: could fix it.  Now
column14: back over here. See
column15: we've got a $4 trillion debt and only in America would you have $2.8 trillion of it or 70% of it financed 5 years or less. Now
column16: that's another thing for you to think about when you go home tonight. You don't finance long-term debt with short-term money. Why did our government do it? To get the interest rates down. A 1% increase in interest rates in that $2.8 trillion is $28 billion a year.  Now
column17: when you look at what Germany pays for money and what we don't pay for money
column18: you realize there's quite a spread
column19: right
column20: and you realize this is a temporary thing and there's going to be another sucking sound that runs our deficit through the roof.  You know
column21: and everybody's ducking it so I'm gonna say it
column22: that we are not letting that surplus stay in the bank. We are not investing that surplus like a pension fund. We are spending that surplus to make the deficit look smaller to you than it really is.  Now
column23: that -- put you in jail in corporate America if you kept books that way but in government it's just kind of the way things are. That's because it comes at you
column24: not from you.  Now then
column25: that money needs to be -- they don't even pay interest on it. They just write a note for the interest.

column1: Do you want to fix the problem or sound-bite it? I understand the importance of time but see
column2: here's how we get to this mess we're in.

column1: This is just 1 of 1000. Now then
column2: to nail it
column3: there's one way out -- a growing
column4: expanding job base. A growing
column5: expanding job base to generate the funds and the tax revenues to pay off the mess and rebuild America. We've got to double-hit. If we're $4 trillion down
column6: we should have everything perfect
column7: but we don't. We've got to pay it off and build money to renew it- -spend money to renew it
column8: and that's going to take a growing
column9: expanding job base. That is priority one in this country. Put everybody that's breathing to work. And I'd love to be out of workers and have to import them
column10: like some of our international competitors.

column1: Sorry.
Okay.
Absolutely. I apologize.
I think I remember the question. (Laughter.) Let me say first of all
column2: I want to answer your specific question but first of all
column3: we all agree that there should be a growing economy. What you have to decide is who's got the best economic plan. And we all have ideas out there
column4: and Mr. Bush has a record. So I don't want you to read my lips and I sure don't want you to read his. I do hope you will read our plans.  Now
column5: specifically
column6: one
column7: on Medicare
column8: it is not true that everyone knows how to fix it. There are different ideas -- the Bush plan
column9: the Perot plan
column10: the Clinton -- we have different ideas. I am convinced
column11: having studied health care for a year hard and talking to hundreds and hundreds of people all across America
column12: that you cannot control the cost of Medicare until you control the cost of private health care and public health care
column13: with managed competition
column14: ceiling on cost
column15: and radical reorganization of the insurance markets. You've got to do that; we got to get those costs down.  Number 2
column16: with regard to Social Security
column17: that program -- a lot of you may not know this -- it produces a $70 billion surplus a year. Social Security is in surplus $70 billion. Six increases in the payroll tax -- that means people with incomes of $51
column18: 000 a year or less pay a disproportionally high share of the federal tax burden
column19: which is why I want some middle-class tax relief.  What do we have to do? By the time the century turns
column20: we have got to have our deficit under control
column21: we have to work out of so that surplus is building up so when the baby boomers like me retire
column23: on the pension funds
column24: I don't know as much about it
column25: but I will say this. What I would do is to bring in the pension experts of the country
column26: take a look at it
column27: and strengthen the pension requirements further
column28: because it's not just enough to have the guarantee. We had a guarantee on the S&Ls
column29: right? We had a guarantee -- and what happened? You picked up a $500-billion bill because of the dumb way the federal government deregulated it.  So I think we are going to have to change and strengthen the pension requirements on private retirement plans.

column4: and Mr. Bush has a record. So I don't want you to read my lips and I sure don't want you to read his. I do hope you will read our plans.  Now
column5: specifically
column6: one
column7: on Medicare
column8: it is not true that everyone knows how to fix it. There are different ideas -- the Bush plan
column9: the Perot plan
column10: the Clinton -- we have different ideas. I am convinced
column11: having studied health care for a year hard and talking to hundreds and hundreds of people all across America
column12: that you cannot control the cost of Medicare until you control the cost of private health care and public health care
column13: with managed competition
column14: ceiling on cost
column15: and radical reorganization of the insurance markets. You've got to do that; we got to get those costs down.  Number 2
column16: with regard to Social Security
column17: that program -- a lot of you may not know this -- it produces a $70 billion surplus a year. Social Security is in surplus $70 billion. Six increases in the payroll tax -- that means people with incomes of $51
column18: 000 a year or less pay a disproportionally high share of the federal tax burden
column19: which is why I want some middle-class tax relief.  What do we have to do? By the time the century turns
column20: we have got to have our deficit under control
column21: we have to work out of so that surplus is building up so when the baby boomers like me retire
column23: on the pension funds
column24: I don't know as much about it
column25: but I will say this. What I would do is to bring in the pension experts of the country
column26: take a look at it
column27: and strengthen the pension requirements further
column28: because it's not just enough to have the guarantee. We had a guarantee on the S&Ls
column29: right? We had a guarantee -- and what happened? You picked up a $500-billion bill because of the dumb way the federal government deregulated it.  So I think we are going to have to change and strengthen the pension requirements on private retirement plans.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 11)	" Well
column4: we have come to that position. Since I became president
column6: 44 countries have gone democratic
column7: no longer totalitarian
column8: no longer living under dictatorship or communist rule. This is exciting. New world order to me means freedom and democracy. I think we will have a continuing responsibility
column9: as the only remaining superpower
column10: to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share
column11: or more than our share
column12: anymore
column13: I believe you are going to just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in the future. NATO
column14: for example
column15: has kept the peace for many
column16: many years
column17: and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.  But the exciting thing is
column18: the fear of nuclear war is down. And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged
column19: as long as I'm president
column20: working to improve things.  You know
column21: it's so easy now to say
column23: cut out foreign aid
column24: we got a problem at home. I think the US has to still have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol
column25: caring for others. Right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia. It's the US that's taken the lead in humanitarian aid into Bosnia. We're doing this all around the world.  Yes
column26: we got problems at home. And I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home. But because of our leadership
column27: because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group
column30: don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war. President Reagan said no
column31: peace through strength. It worked. The Soviet Union is no more
column32: and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the Freedom Support Act that I led on
column34: Bob Strauss
column36: Jim Baker
column37: all of us got this thing passed -- through cooperation
column38: Ross -- it worked with cooperation
column41: helping Russia become democratic.  So the new world order to me means freedom and democracy
column43: do not pull back into isolation. And we are the US
column44: and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security.  If it hadn't been for us
column45: Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons. And only the US could do this. Excuse me

column1: Well
column2: it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War. Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one
column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons
column4: the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements
column5: but they are still there. With all this instability and breaking into republics
column6: and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons
column7: we've got our work cut out for us. So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.  We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work. See
column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column3: 11)	" Well
column4: we have come to that position. Since I became president
column6: 44 countries have gone democratic
column7: no longer totalitarian
column8: no longer living under dictatorship or communist rule. This is exciting. New world order to me means freedom and democracy. I think we will have a continuing responsibility
column9: as the only remaining superpower
column10: to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share
column11: or more than our share
column12: anymore
column13: I believe you are going to just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in the future. NATO
column14: for example
column15: has kept the peace for many
column16: many years
column17: and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.  But the exciting thing is
column18: the fear of nuclear war is down. And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged
column19: as long as I'm president
column20: working to improve things.  You know
column21: it's so easy now to say
column23: cut out foreign aid
column24: we got a problem at home. I think the US has to still have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol
column25: caring for others. Right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia. It's the US that's taken the lead in humanitarian aid into Bosnia. We're doing this all around the world.  Yes
column26: we got problems at home. And I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home. But because of our leadership
column27: because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group
column30: don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war. President Reagan said no
column31: peace through strength. It worked. The Soviet Union is no more
column32: and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the Freedom Support Act that I led on
column34: Bob Strauss
column36: Jim Baker
column37: all of us got this thing passed -- through cooperation
column38: Ross -- it worked with cooperation
column41: helping Russia become democratic.  So the new world order to me means freedom and democracy
column43: do not pull back into isolation. And we are the US
column44: and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security.  If it hadn't been for us
column45: Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons. And only the US could do this. Excuse me

column1: Well
column2: it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War. Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one
column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons
column4: the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements
column5: but they are still there. With all this instability and breaking into republics
column6: and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons
column7: we've got our work cut out for us. So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.  We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work. See
column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column10: to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share
column11: or more than our share
column12: anymore
column13: I believe you are going to just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in the future. NATO
column14: for example
column15: has kept the peace for many
column16: many years
column17: and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.  But the exciting thing is
column18: the fear of nuclear war is down. And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged
column19: as long as I'm president
column20: working to improve things.  You know
column21: it's so easy now to say
column23: cut out foreign aid
column24: we got a problem at home. I think the US has to still have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol
column25: caring for others. Right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia. It's the US that's taken the lead in humanitarian aid into Bosnia. We're doing this all around the world.  Yes
column26: we got problems at home. And I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home. But because of our leadership
column27: because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group
column30: don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war. President Reagan said no
column31: peace through strength. It worked. The Soviet Union is no more
column32: and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the Freedom Support Act that I led on
column34: Bob Strauss
column36: Jim Baker
column37: all of us got this thing passed -- through cooperation
column38: Ross -- it worked with cooperation
column41: helping Russia become democratic.  So the new world order to me means freedom and democracy
column43: do not pull back into isolation. And we are the US
column44: and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security.  If it hadn't been for us
column45: Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons. And only the US could do this. Excuse me

column1: Well
column2: it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War. Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one
column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons
column4: the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements
column5: but they are still there. With all this instability and breaking into republics
column6: and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons
column7: we've got our work cut out for us. So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.  We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work. See
column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column6: 44 countries have gone democratic
column7: no longer totalitarian
column8: no longer living under dictatorship or communist rule. This is exciting. New world order to me means freedom and democracy. I think we will have a continuing responsibility
column9: as the only remaining superpower
column10: to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share
column11: or more than our share

column18: the fear of nuclear war is down. And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged
column19: as long as I'm president
column20: working to improve things.  You know
column21: it's so easy now to say

column27: because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group
column30: don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war. President Reagan said no

column1: Well
column2: it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War. Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one
column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons
column4: the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements
column5: but they are still there. With all this instability and breaking into republics
column6: and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons
column7: we've got our work cut out for us. So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.  We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work. See
column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 11)	" Well
column4: we have come to that position. Since I became president
column6: 44 countries have gone democratic
column7: no longer totalitarian
column8: no longer living under dictatorship or communist rule. This is exciting. New world order to me means freedom and democracy. I think we will have a continuing responsibility
column9: as the only remaining superpower
column10: to stay involved. If we pull back in some isolation and say we don't have to do our share
column11: or more than our share
column12: anymore
column13: I believe you are going to just ask for conflagration that we'll get involved in the future. NATO
column14: for example
column15: has kept the peace for many
column16: many years
column17: and I want to see us keep fully staffed in NATO so we'll continue to guarantee the peace in Europe.  But the exciting thing is
column18: the fear of nuclear war is down. And you hear all the bad stuff that's happened on my watch; I hope people will recognize that this is something pretty good for mankind. I hope they'll think it's good that democracy and freedom is on the move. And we're going to stay engaged
column19: as long as I'm president
column20: working to improve things.  You know
column21: it's so easy now to say
column23: cut out foreign aid
column24: we got a problem at home. I think the US has to still have the Statue of Liberty as a symbol
column25: caring for others. Right this very minute we're sending supplies in to help these little starving kids in Somalia. It's the US that's taken the lead in humanitarian aid into Bosnia. We're doing this all around the world.  Yes
column26: we got problems at home. And I think I got a good plan to help fix those problems at home. But because of our leadership
column27: because we didn't listen to the freeze -- the nuclear-freeze group
column30: don't touch it; we're going to lock it in now or else we'll have war. President Reagan said no
column31: peace through strength. It worked. The Soviet Union is no more
column32: and now we're working to help them become totally democratic through the Freedom Support Act that I led on
column34: Bob Strauss
column36: Jim Baker
column37: all of us got this thing passed -- through cooperation
column38: Ross -- it worked with cooperation
column41: helping Russia become democratic.  So the new world order to me means freedom and democracy
column43: do not pull back into isolation. And we are the US
column44: and we have a responsibility to lead and to guarantee the security.  If it hadn't been for us
column45: Saddam Hussein would be sitting on top of three-fifths of the oil supply of the world and he'd have nuclear weapons. And only the US could do this. Excuse me

column1: Well
column2: it's cost-effective to help Russia succeed in its revolution; it's pennies on the dollar compared to going back to the Cold War. Russia is still very unstable; they could go back to square one
column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons
column4: the ones that can hit us. We've got agreements
column5: but they are still there. With all this instability and breaking into republics
column6: and all the Middle Eastern countries going over there and shopping for weapons
column7: we've got our work cut out for us. So we need to stay right on top of that and constructively help them move toward democracy and capitalism.  We have to have money to do that. We have to have our people at work. See
column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column3: and worse. All the nuclear weapons are not dismantled. I am particularly concerned about the intercontinental weapons

column8: for 45 years we were preoccupied with the Red Army. I suggest now that our number one preoccupation is red ink and our country and we've got to put our people back to work so that we can afford to do these things we want to do in Russia. We cannot be the policeman for the world any longer. We spent $300 billion a year defending the world. Germany and Japan spend around $30 billion a piece. If I can get you to defend me and I can spend all my money building industry that's a home run for me.  Coming out of World War II it made sense. Now
column9: the other superpowers need to do their part. I'll close on this point. You can't be a superpower unless you're an economic superpower. If we're not an economic superpower
column10: we're a used to be and we will no longer be a force for good throughout the world. And if nothing else gets you excited about rebuilding our industrial base maybe that will because job one is to put our people back to work.

column1: I'd rather answer her question first and then I'll be glad to. Because the question you ask is important. The end of the Cold War brings an incredible opportunity for change. Winds of freedom blowing around the world
column2: Russia demilitarizing. And it also requires us to maintain some continuity -- some bipartisan American commitment to certain principles. And I would just say there are three things that I would like to say -- number one -- we do have to maintain the world's strongest defense. We may differ about what the elements of that are. I think that defense needs to be -- with fewer people in permanent armed services but with greater mobility on the land
column3: in the air and on the sea
column4: with a real dedication to continuing development of high technology weaponry and well trained people. I think we're going to have to work to stop the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction. Got to keep going until all those nuclear weapons in Russia are gone and the other republics. Number 2
column5: if you don't rebuild the economic strength of this country at home
column6: we won't be a superpower. We can't have any more instances like what happened when Mr. Bush went to Japan and the Japanese prime minister said he felt sympathy for our country. We have to be the strongest economic power in the world. That's what got me into this race
column7: so we could rebuild the American economy.  And number three
column8: we need to be a force for freedom and democracy and we need to use our unique position to support freedom
column9: whether it's in Haiti or in China or in any other place
column10: wherever the seeds of freedom are sprouting. We can't impose it
column11: but we need to nourish it and that's the kind of thing that I would do as president -- follow those three commitments into the future.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 13)	" Well
column4: I don't have any idea but I hope it will happen some time in my lifetime.

column1: I believe that this country is electing more and more African Americans and Latinos and Asian Americans who are representing districts that are themselves not necessarily of a majority of their race. The American people are beginning to vote across racial lines
column2: and I hope it will happen more and more. More and more women are being elected. Look at all these women Senate candidates we have here. And you know
column3: according to my mother and my wife and my daughter
column4: this world would be a lot better place if women were running it most of the time.  I do think there are special experiences and judgments and backgrounds and understandings that women bring to this process
column5: by the way. This lady said here
column6: how have you been affected by the economy. I mean
column7: women know what's it like to be paid an unequal amount for equal work. They know what it's like not to have flexible working hours. They know what it's like not to have family leave or childcare. So I think it would be a good thing for America if it happened. And I think it will happen in my lifetime.

column1: I think if Barbara Bush were running this year she'd be elected. But it's too late. (Laughter) You don't want us to mention appointees
column2: but when you see the quality of people in our administration
column3: see how Colin Powell performed -- I say administration --

column1: You weren't impressed with the fact that he --
Yeah
column2: but wouldn't that suggest to the American people
column3: then
column4: here's a quality person
column5: if he decided that he could automatically get the nomination of either party?

column1: Huh?

column2: I see.

column1: You mean
column2: time?

column1: I don't know -- starting after 4 years.

column2: I think you'll see --

column1: I think you'll see more minority candidates and women candidates coming forward.
This is supposed to be the year of the women in the Senate. Let's see how they do. I hope a lot of --
I have a fearless forecast. A message just won't do it. Colin Powell will be on somebody's ticket 4 years from now -- right? Right? He wanted that said -- 4 years.
Now
column2: if won't be
column3: General Waller would be -- you say
column4: why do you keep picking military people. These are people that I just happen to know and have a high regard for. I'm sure there are hundreds of others.

column1: How about Dr. Lou Sullivan?
Absolutely.
Yeah
column2: a good man.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 14)	" May I ask for an exception because I think we owe Carole Simpson -- anybody who can stand in between these three characters here and get the job done -- we owe her a round of applause. (Applause) But don't take it out of my time! (Applause)

column1: I feel strongly about it because I don't want it to come out of my time.
No
column2: but let me just stay to the American people in 2 and a half weeks we're going to choose who should sit in this Oval Office
column3: who to lead the economic recovery
column4: who to be the leader of the free world
column5: who to get the deficit down. three ways to do that. One is to raise taxes. One is to reduce spending -- controlling that mandatory spending. Another one is to invest and save and to stimulate growth. I do not want to raise taxes. I differ with the 2 here on that. I'm just not going to do that. I do believe that we need to control mandatory spending. I think we need to invest and save more. I believe that we need to educate better and retrain better. I believe that we need to export more so I'll keep working for export agreements where we can sell more abroad and I believe that we must strengthen the family. We've got to strengthen the family.  Now
column6: let me pose this question to America. If in the next 5 minutes a television announcer came on and said
column7: there is a major international crisis -- there is a major threat to the world or in this country a major threat -- my question is
column8: who
column9: if you were appointed to name 1 of the 3 of us
column10: who would you choose? Who has the perseverance
column11: the character
column12: the integrity
column13: the maturity
column14: to get the job done? I hope I'm that person. Thank you very
column15: very much.

column1: If the American people want to do it and not talk about it
column2: then they ought to -- you know
column3: I'm one person they ought to consider. If they just want to keep slow dancing and talk about it and not do it
column4: I'm not your man. I am results oriented. I am action oriented. I've dealt my businesses. Getting things done in three months that my competitors took 18 months to do. Everybody says you can't do that with Congress. Sure
column5: you can do that with Congress. Congress -- they're all good people. They're all patriots but you've got to link arms and work with them. Sure
column6: you'll have arguments. Sure
column7: you'll have fights. We have them all day every day. But we get the job done.  Now
column8: I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education. I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged little children. And let me tell you one specific pilot program where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3. Now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant and they'll start right after they're born.  Starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9 and then going into the public school in the 4th grade. Ninety percent are on the honor role. Now that will change America. Those children will all go to college. They will live the American dream. And I beg the American people
column9: any time they think about reforming education to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children and teach them that they're unique and that they're precious and that there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom. And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific.  Now
column10: finally
column11: if you can't pay the bills you're dead in the water. And we have got to put our nation back to work. Now
column12: if you don't want to really do that I'm not your man. I'd go crazy sitting up there slow dancing that one. In other words
column13: unless we're going to do it
column14: then pick somebody who likes to talk about it.  Now
column15: just remember when you think about me -- I didn't create this mess. I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows
column16: I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes. And for a guy that started out with everything he owned in the trunk of his car --

column1: -- that ain't bad.
But it's in your hands. I wish you well. I'll see you tomorrow night -- (Laughter) on NBC -- 10:30 to 11:00 Eastern Time. (Laughter)
Thank you
column2: Carole
column3: and thank you
column4: ladies and gentlemen. Since I suggested this format I hope it's been good for all of you. I really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly. I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this a more positive experience.  These problems are not easy. They're not going to be solved overnight. But I want you to think about just 2 or 3 things. First of all
column5: the people of my state have let me be their governor for 12 years because I made commitments to 2 things -- more jobs and better schools.  Our schools are now better. Our children get off to a better start from pre-school programs and smaller classes in the early grades
column6: and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth
column7: 4th in manufacturing in job growth
column8: 4th in income growth
column9: 4th in the decline of poverty.  I'm proud of that. It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals
column10: hundreds of business people
column11: many of them Republican
column12: support this campaign.  You have to decide whether you want to change or not. We do not need 4 more years of an economic theory that doesn't work. We've had 12 years of trickle down economics. It's time to put the American people first
column13: to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly. But you cannot just get there by balancing the budget. We've got to grow the economy by putting people first -- real people like you.  I got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than her parents. We're better than that. We can do better than that. I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it.  Thank you very much.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 14)	" May I ask for an exception because I think we owe Carole Simpson -- anybody who can stand in between these three characters here and get the job done -- we owe her a round of applause. (Applause) But don't take it out of my time! (Applause)

column1: I feel strongly about it because I don't want it to come out of my time.
No
column2: but let me just stay to the American people in 2 and a half weeks we're going to choose who should sit in this Oval Office
column3: who to lead the economic recovery
column4: who to be the leader of the free world
column5: who to get the deficit down. three ways to do that. One is to raise taxes. One is to reduce spending -- controlling that mandatory spending. Another one is to invest and save and to stimulate growth. I do not want to raise taxes. I differ with the 2 here on that. I'm just not going to do that. I do believe that we need to control mandatory spending. I think we need to invest and save more. I believe that we need to educate better and retrain better. I believe that we need to export more so I'll keep working for export agreements where we can sell more abroad and I believe that we must strengthen the family. We've got to strengthen the family.  Now
column6: let me pose this question to America. If in the next 5 minutes a television announcer came on and said
column7: there is a major international crisis -- there is a major threat to the world or in this country a major threat -- my question is
column8: who
column9: if you were appointed to name 1 of the 3 of us
column10: who would you choose? Who has the perseverance
column11: the character
column12: the integrity
column13: the maturity
column14: to get the job done? I hope I'm that person. Thank you very
column15: very much.

column1: If the American people want to do it and not talk about it
column2: then they ought to -- you know
column3: I'm one person they ought to consider. If they just want to keep slow dancing and talk about it and not do it
column4: I'm not your man. I am results oriented. I am action oriented. I've dealt my businesses. Getting things done in three months that my competitors took 18 months to do. Everybody says you can't do that with Congress. Sure
column5: you can do that with Congress. Congress -- they're all good people. They're all patriots but you've got to link arms and work with them. Sure
column6: you'll have arguments. Sure
column7: you'll have fights. We have them all day every day. But we get the job done.  Now
column8: I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education. I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged little children. And let me tell you one specific pilot program where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3. Now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant and they'll start right after they're born.  Starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9 and then going into the public school in the 4th grade. Ninety percent are on the honor role. Now that will change America. Those children will all go to college. They will live the American dream. And I beg the American people
column9: any time they think about reforming education to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children and teach them that they're unique and that they're precious and that there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom. And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific.  Now
column10: finally
column11: if you can't pay the bills you're dead in the water. And we have got to put our nation back to work. Now
column12: if you don't want to really do that I'm not your man. I'd go crazy sitting up there slow dancing that one. In other words
column13: unless we're going to do it
column14: then pick somebody who likes to talk about it.  Now
column15: just remember when you think about me -- I didn't create this mess. I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows
column16: I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes. And for a guy that started out with everything he owned in the trunk of his car --

column1: -- that ain't bad.
But it's in your hands. I wish you well. I'll see you tomorrow night -- (Laughter) on NBC -- 10:30 to 11:00 Eastern Time. (Laughter)
Thank you
column2: Carole
column3: and thank you
column4: ladies and gentlemen. Since I suggested this format I hope it's been good for all of you. I really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly. I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this a more positive experience.  These problems are not easy. They're not going to be solved overnight. But I want you to think about just 2 or 3 things. First of all
column5: the people of my state have let me be their governor for 12 years because I made commitments to 2 things -- more jobs and better schools.  Our schools are now better. Our children get off to a better start from pre-school programs and smaller classes in the early grades
column6: and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth
column7: 4th in manufacturing in job growth
column8: 4th in income growth
column9: 4th in the decline of poverty.  I'm proud of that. It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals
column10: hundreds of business people
column11: many of them Republican
column12: support this campaign.  You have to decide whether you want to change or not. We do not need 4 more years of an economic theory that doesn't work. We've had 12 years of trickle down economics. It's time to put the American people first
column13: to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly. But you cannot just get there by balancing the budget. We've got to grow the economy by putting people first -- real people like you.  I got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than her parents. We're better than that. We can do better than that. I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it.  Thank you very much.

column5: you can do that with Congress. Congress -- they're all good people. They're all patriots but you've got to link arms and work with them. Sure
column6: you'll have arguments. Sure
column7: you'll have fights. We have them all day every day. But we get the job done.  Now
column8: I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education. I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged little children. And let me tell you one specific pilot program where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3. Now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant and they'll start right after they're born.  Starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9 and then going into the public school in the 4th grade. Ninety percent are on the honor role. Now that will change America. Those children will all go to college. They will live the American dream. And I beg the American people
column9: any time they think about reforming education to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children and teach them that they're unique and that they're precious and that there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom. And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific.  Now
column10: finally
column11: if you can't pay the bills you're dead in the water. And we have got to put our nation back to work. Now
column12: if you don't want to really do that I'm not your man. I'd go crazy sitting up there slow dancing that one. In other words
column13: unless we're going to do it
column14: then pick somebody who likes to talk about it.  Now
column15: just remember when you think about me -- I didn't create this mess. I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows
column16: I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes. And for a guy that started out with everything he owned in the trunk of his car --

column1: -- that ain't bad.
But it's in your hands. I wish you well. I'll see you tomorrow night -- (Laughter) on NBC -- 10:30 to 11:00 Eastern Time. (Laughter)
Thank you
column2: Carole
column3: and thank you
column4: ladies and gentlemen. Since I suggested this format I hope it's been good for all of you. I really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly. I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this a more positive experience.  These problems are not easy. They're not going to be solved overnight. But I want you to think about just 2 or 3 things. First of all
column5: the people of my state have let me be their governor for 12 years because I made commitments to 2 things -- more jobs and better schools.  Our schools are now better. Our children get off to a better start from pre-school programs and smaller classes in the early grades
column6: and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth
column7: 4th in manufacturing in job growth
column8: 4th in income growth
column9: 4th in the decline of poverty.  I'm proud of that. It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals
column10: hundreds of business people
column11: many of them Republican
column12: support this campaign.  You have to decide whether you want to change or not. We do not need 4 more years of an economic theory that doesn't work. We've had 12 years of trickle down economics. It's time to put the American people first
column13: to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly. But you cannot just get there by balancing the budget. We've got to grow the economy by putting people first -- real people like you.  I got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than her parents. We're better than that. We can do better than that. I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it.  Thank you very much.

column6: and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth

column13: to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly. column2: '15Oct'
column3: 14)	" May I ask for an exception because I think we owe Carole Simpson -- anybody who can stand in between these three characters here and get the job done -- we owe her a round of applause. (Applause) But don't take it out of my time! (Applause)

column1: I feel strongly about it because I don't want it to come out of my time.
No
column2: but let me just stay to the American people in 2 and a half weeks we're going to choose who should sit in this Oval Office
column3: who to lead the economic recovery
column4: who to be the leader of the free world
column5: who to get the deficit down. three ways to do that. One is to raise taxes. One is to reduce spending -- controlling that mandatory spending. Another one is to invest and save and to stimulate growth. I do not want to raise taxes. I differ with the 2 here on that. I'm just not going to do that. I do believe that we need to control mandatory spending. I think we need to invest and save more. I believe that we need to educate better and retrain better. I believe that we need to export more so I'll keep working for export agreements where we can sell more abroad and I believe that we must strengthen the family. We've got to strengthen the family.  Now
column6: let me pose this question to America. If in the next 5 minutes a television announcer came on and said
column7: there is a major international crisis -- there is a major threat to the world or in this country a major threat -- my question is
column8: who
column9: if you were appointed to name 1 of the 3 of us
column10: who would you choose? Who has the perseverance
column11: the character
column12: the integrity
column13: the maturity
column14: to get the job done? I hope I'm that person. Thank you very
column15: very much.

column1: If the American people want to do it and not talk about it
column2: then they ought to -- you know
column3: I'm one person they ought to consider. If they just want to keep slow dancing and talk about it and not do it
column4: I'm not your man. I am results oriented. I am action oriented. I've dealt my businesses. Getting things done in three months that my competitors took 18 months to do. Everybody says you can't do that with Congress. Sure
column5: you can do that with Congress. Congress -- they're all good people. They're all patriots but you've got to link arms and work with them. Sure
column6: you'll have arguments. Sure
column7: you'll have fights. We have them all day every day. But we get the job done.  Now
column8: I have to come back in my clothes to one thing because I am passionate about education. I was talking about early childhood education for disadvantaged little children. And let me tell you one specific pilot program where children who don't have a chance go to this program when they're 3. Now we're going back to when the mother's pregnant and they'll start right after they're born.  Starting when they're 3 and going to this school until they're 9 and then going into the public school in the 4th grade. Ninety percent are on the honor role. Now that will change America. Those children will all go to college. They will live the American dream. And I beg the American people
column9: any time they think about reforming education to take this piece of society that doesn't have a chance and take these little pieces of clay that can be shaped and molded and give them the same love and nurture and affection and support you give your children and teach them that they're unique and that they're precious and that there's only one person in the world like them and you will see this nation bloom. And we will have so many people who are qualified for the top job that it will be terrific.  Now
column10: finally
column11: if you can't pay the bills you're dead in the water. And we have got to put our nation back to work. Now
column12: if you don't want to really do that I'm not your man. I'd go crazy sitting up there slow dancing that one. In other words
column13: unless we're going to do it
column14: then pick somebody who likes to talk about it.  Now
column15: just remember when you think about me -- I didn't create this mess. I've been paying taxes just like you and Lord knows
column16: I've paid my share -- over a billion in taxes. And for a guy that started out with everything he owned in the trunk of his car --

column1: -- that ain't bad.
But it's in your hands. I wish you well. I'll see you tomorrow night -- (Laughter) on NBC -- 10:30 to 11:00 Eastern Time. (Laughter)
Thank you
column2: Carole
column3: and thank you
column4: ladies and gentlemen. Since I suggested this format I hope it's been good for all of you. I really tried to be faithful to your request that we answer the questions specifically and pointedly. I thought I owed that to you and I respect you for being here and for the impact you've had on making this a more positive experience.  These problems are not easy. They're not going to be solved overnight. But I want you to think about just 2 or 3 things. First of all
column5: the people of my state have let me be their governor for 12 years because I made commitments to 2 things -- more jobs and better schools.  Our schools are now better. Our children get off to a better start from pre-school programs and smaller classes in the early grades
column6: and we have one of the most aggressive adult education programs in the country. We talked about that. This year my state ranks first in the country in job growth
column7: 4th in manufacturing in job growth
column8: 4th in income growth
column9: 4th in the decline of poverty.  I'm proud of that. It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals
column10: hundreds of business people
column11: many of them Republican
column12: support this campaign.  You have to decide whether you want to change or not. We do not need 4 more years of an economic theory that doesn't work. We've had 12 years of trickle down economics. It's time to put the American people first
column13: to invest and grow this economy. I'm the only person here who's ever balanced a government budget and I've presented 12 of them and cut spending repeatedly. But you cannot just get there by balancing the budget. We've got to grow the economy by putting people first -- real people like you.  I got into this race because I did not want my child to grow up to be part of the first generation of Americans to do worse than her parents. We're better than that. We can do better than that. I want to make America as great as it can be and I ask for your help in doing it.  Thank you very much.

column1: It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals, hundreds of business people, many of them Republican, support this campaign. column1: Who do you want to start with?
It caused me to disrupt my private life and my business to get involved in this activity. That's how much I care about it. And believe me
column2: if you knew my family and if you knew the private life I have
column3: you would agree in a minute that that's a whole lot more fun than getting involved in politics. But I have lived the American dream. I came from very modest background. Nobody's been luckier than I've been
column4: all the way across the spectrum
column5: and the greatest riches of all are my wife and children. That's true of any family.  But I want all the children -- I want these young people up here to be able to start with nothing but an idea like I did and build a business. But they've got to have a strong basic economy and if you're in debt
column6: it's like having a ball and chain around you.  I just figure
column7: as lucky as I've been
column8: I owe it to them and I owe it to the future generations and on a very personal basis
column9: I owe it to my children and grandchildren.

column1: Well
column2: I think the national debt affects everybody.

column1: Obviously it has a lot to do with interest rates --
I'm sure it has. I love my grandchildren --

I want to think that they're going to be able to afford an education. I think that that's an important part of being a parent. If the question -- maybe I -- get it wrong. Are you suggesting that if somebody has means that the national debt doesn't affect them?
I'm not sure I get -- help me with the question and I'll try to answer it.
Yeah.
Well
column2: listen
column3: you ought to be in the White House for a day and hear what I hear and see what I see and read the mail I read and touch the people that I touch from time to time. I was in the Lomax AME Church. It's a black church just outside of Washington
column4: DC. And I read in the bulletin about teenage pregnancies
column5: about the difficulties that families are having to make ends meet. I talk to parents. I mean
column6: you've got to care. Everybody cares if people aren't doing well. But I don't think it's fair to say
column7: you haven't had cancer. Therefore
column8: you don't know what's it like. I don't think it's fair to say
column9: you know
column10: whatever it is
column11: that if you haven't been hit by it personally. But everybody's affected by the debt because of the tremendous interest that goes into paying on that debt everything's more expensive. Everything comes out of your pocket and my pocket. So it's that.  But I think in terms of the recession
column12: of course you feel it when you're president of the US. And that's why I'm trying to do something about it by stimulating the export
column13: vesting more
column14: better education systems.  Thank you. I'm glad you clarified it.

column1: Tell me how it's affected you again.
You know people who've lost their jobs and lost their homes?
Well
column2: I've been governor of a small state for 12 years. I'll tell you how it's affected me. Every year Congress and the president sign laws that make us do more things and gives us less money to do it with. I see people in my state
column3: middle class people -- their taxes have gone up in Washington and their services have gone down while the wealthy have gotten tax cuts. I have seen what's happened in this last 4 years when -- in my state
column4: when people lose their jobs there's a good chance I'll know them by their names. When a factory closes
column5: I know the people who ran it. When the businesses go bankrupt
column6: I know them.  And I've been out here for 13 months meeting in meetings just like this ever since October
column7: with people like you all over America
column8: people that have lost their jobs
column9: lost their livelihood
column10: lost their health insurance.  What I want you to understand is the national debt is not the only cause of that. It is because America has not invested in its people. It is because we have not grown. It is because we've had 12 years of trickle down economics. We've gone from first to twelfth in the world in wages. We've had 4 years where we've produced no private sector jobs. Most people are working harder for less money than they were making ten years ago.  It is because we are in the grip of a failed economic theory. And this decision you're about to make better be about what kind of economic theory you want
column11: not just people saying I'm going to go fix it but what are we going to do? I think we have to do is invest in American jobs
column12: American education
column13: control American health care costs and bring the American people together again.

column2: '15Oct'
column3: 9)	" May I answer that?

column1: Who do you want to start with?
It caused me to disrupt my private life and my business to get involved in this activity. That's how much I care about it. And believe me
column2: if you knew my family and if you knew the private life I have
column3: you would agree in a minute that that's a whole lot more fun than getting involved in politics. But I have lived the American dream. I came from very modest background. Nobody's been luckier than I've been
column4: all the way across the spectrum
column5: and the greatest riches of all are my wife and children. That's true of any family.  But I want all the children -- I want these young people up here to be able to start with nothing but an idea like I did and build a business. But they've got to have a strong basic economy and if you're in debt
column6: it's like having a ball and chain around you.  I just figure
column7: as lucky as I've been
column8: I owe it to them and I owe it to the future generations and on a very personal basis
column9: I owe it to my children and grandchildren.

column1: Well
column2: I think the national debt affects everybody.

column1: Obviously it has a lot to do with interest rates --
I'm sure it has. I love my grandchildren --

I want to think that they're going to be able to afford an education. I think that that's an important part of being a parent. If the question -- maybe I -- get it wrong. Are you suggesting that if somebody has means that the national debt doesn't affect them?
I'm not sure I get -- help me with the question and I'll try to answer it.
Yeah.
Well
column2: listen
column3: you ought to be in the White House for a day and hear what I hear and see what I see and read the mail I read and touch the people that I touch from time to time. I was in the Lomax AME Church. It's a black church just outside of Washington
column4: DC. And I read in the bulletin about teenage pregnancies
column5: about the difficulties that families are having to make ends meet. I talk to parents. I mean
column6: you've got to care. Everybody cares if people aren't doing well. But I don't think it's fair to say
column7: you haven't had cancer. Therefore
column8: you don't know what's it like. I don't think it's fair to say
column9: you know
column10: whatever it is
column11: that if you haven't been hit by it personally. But everybody's affected by the debt because of the tremendous interest that goes into paying on that debt everything's more expensive. Everything comes out of your pocket and my pocket. So it's that.  But I think in terms of the recession
column12: of course you feel it when you're president of the US. And that's why I'm trying to do something about it by stimulating the export
column13: vesting more
column14: better education systems.  Thank you. I'm glad you clarified it.

column1: Tell me how it's affected you again.
You know people who've lost their jobs and lost their homes?
Well
column2: I've been governor of a small state for 12 years. I'll tell you how it's affected me. Every year Congress and the president sign laws that make us do more things and gives us less money to do it with. I see people in my state
column3: middle class people -- their taxes have gone up in Washington and their services have gone down while the wealthy have gotten tax cuts. I have seen what's happened in this last 4 years when -- in my state
column4: when people lose their jobs there's a good chance I'll know them by their names. When a factory closes
column5: I know the people who ran it. When the businesses go bankrupt
column6: I know them.  And I've been out here for 13 months meeting in meetings just like this ever since October
column7: with people like you all over America
column8: people that have lost their jobs
column9: lost their livelihood
column10: lost their health insurance.  What I want you to understand is the national debt is not the only cause of that. It is because America has not invested in its people. It is because we have not grown. It is because we've had 12 years of trickle down economics. We've gone from first to twelfth in the world in wages. We've had 4 years where we've produced no private sector jobs. Most people are working harder for less money than they were making ten years ago.  It is because we are in the grip of a failed economic theory. And this decision you're about to make better be about what kind of economic theory you want
column11: not just people saying I'm going to go fix it but what are we going to do? I think we have to do is invest in American jobs
column12: American education
column13: control American health care costs and bring the American people together again.

column1: And I read in the bulletin about teenage pregnancies, about the difficulties that families are having to make ends meet. I talk to parents. I mean, you've got to care. Everybody cares if people aren't doing well.
